title: This case has DLC! - InWin ModFree
description: Get your overpriced stickers at   InWin makes a ton of interesting cases, and at CES, they were showing off their new ModFree case that allows you to expand and customize your case however you like with a unique mounting mechanism that lets you grow your case with modules so we sent Adam to see if this system lets you create the perfect case or if it makes your PC build needlessly complicated.   Want us to unbox something? Make a suggestion at    SUBSCRIBE ON FLOATPLANE:    GET MERCH:   AFFILIATES, SPONSORS & REFERRALS:   PODCAST GEAR:   SUPPORT US ON FLOATPLANE:   FOLLOW US ELSEWHERE ---------------------------------------------------   Twitter:  Instagram:  TikTok:  Facebook:   CHAPTERS --------------------------------------------------- 0:00 Adam rips apart a PC with his hands 0:55 What's included and various configurations 3:24 Main case tour and panel type options 4:54 Sponsor - dbrand 6:07 An oddity and modules we want 7:00 Who's this for? 7:42 Outro
transcript: - This is the brand new ModFree PC case from InWin. Looks pretty nice, huh? But maybe it's a little big. Well, don't worry about that because the whole top just comes off. Actually, this comes off too. This also just kinda comes off, but we expect that. And this comes off. And you can actually take the whole front off, if you really wanna, because the whole computer is modular. That's right, every single prism in this whole beast of a machine can be just totally removed. Completely toolless, completely simple. Let's take a look over here. The whole idea behind this case is that you only have to buy what you need when you need it. So you don't have to fret over being like, "Oh, I wanna get this small case, but what if I want more storage in the future? I don't have enough drive mounts." Well, at any point, you can just get yourself an expansion module that toollessly attaches right at the top or at the bottom or at the sides even. With the base version of the case, you get two modules: the motherboard module and the PSU module. You would put them, I don't know, I guess together in like this kind of, you know, a traditional format with a bottom-mounted power supply. And then you would be able to put any side panels or top panels that you want on it. And you can get a 280-millimeter rad that can be mounted at the top or at the front. It also comes with a mount for your storage. So you can have two 2.5-inch drives or one 3.5-inch drive. And the cool thing is that you can kind of put it wherever you want. You wanna put it up here? You can. You just gotta screw it in. You wanna put it further back? You can do that, too, and at the bottom. You can even put 'em at the front. And the storage module will hold up to eight 3.5-inch drives, which will allow you to basically transform this into your NAS if you want. Or you can put a whole other computer in just the expansion module. Currently supports an SFX power supply, and as you can see, an m-ITX motherboard. So if you're a streamer and you wanna have a dedicated stream computer, or if you're somebody who wants to have network-attached storage, but you don't wanna have to have another computer sitting somewhere else, you can literally just, I don't know, put this on the side, put this on the front. Maybe not, probably not the best airflow configuration to put a whole other computer on the front of your other computer, but hey, I don't make the rules. You do, and that's the beauty. You can just have your base computer with a bottom-mounted PSU. Or you can actually put the module on the top if that's what you prefer. And if you go, "Uh-oh, maybe I need more cooling for that new 4090 I'm getting," well, you can add another module or two modules or even three more modules, which is, this is the Mod tier that InWin is also gonna be selling. There's a extra expansion module on the back. You can see three fans, another module down there, another module on the front. Each of the expansion modules can hold up to a 420-millimeter rad. And you don't have to worry about compatibility because you're not gonna deal with your radiator going over your motherboard and blocking some of the ports or whatever. You just have this whole extra section. One thing that's interesting is that, currently, all of the modules that they have here at CES are longer than the horizontal length of the case. So if you want to add something on top, it's gonna look a little weird. It's gonna have a bit of a pompadour. But you can always add it to the front, right, for again, that better rad support. One thing I would also like to see is maybe a change to this mechanism. Right now, it's just kind of a piece of metal. I think if they added maybe just some, like, rubber around the edges, that would really make it nice. This is pre-production, and they're looking for feedback. So if this seems like something that you don't really care about, then maybe they won't change it. Or do a favor for me and tell 'em to put rubber on it. That's enough about the modules. Let's get back to the main case and look at some of the features that we have. You have some rubber grommets for cable management. You also have a lot of options for cable management. This is great because you don't know where your cables are gonna go. You can put your PSU on the front, top, or the back. So they have to give this kind of extra space to accommodate any configuration, which is a pretty unique design challenge, because a lot of times, when you're making a case, you have something in mind of how it's supposed to go. And that allows you to be like, "We only need these options." You have about an inch of clearance on the back end for cables. You have some tie-down points. Here's some mounting points for, like, your RGB controller if you're going, like, full RGB. One thing I would like to see is maybe a mounting point for a 2.5-inch drive in the back. Because this is probably going to be the core of your system, I want this part to have as much flexibility as possible so that I don't feel like I'm forced to upgrade as opposed to just having the opportunity to upgrade. Also, this can support up to EATX motherboards. You see the mounting holes up here, so you can go really big with your motherboard if you're trying to do a crazy system like that one over there. Not that this is hard to use, but you'll be cheaper going with, like, a high-volume case from, I don't know, you know, your Phanteks, Corsair, kind of stuff like that. But for somebody who goes, "I know what I want now, and I have an idea of what I want in the future," I think this is really exciting because you're not gonna be tied down to that case.
